The margin of error for a specific poll is determined by several factors, including the sample size, the level of confidence desired, and the estimated population size.

To calculate the margin of error, statisticians use a formula that takes into account the sample size and a level of confidence desired. The formula usually assumes that the sample was selected randomly and that the participants are representative of the population being studied.

For example, to calculate the margin of error with a 95% level of confidence, the formula used by most pollsters is:

Margin of error = 1 / square root of sample size

If a poll has a sample size of 1000 voters, the margin of error would be approximately 3.2%. This means that if the same poll were repeated many times, the results would be expected to vary by no more than 3.2% in either direction, 95% of the time.

It is important to note that the margin of error is just one of many factors to consider when evaluating the accuracy of a poll. Other factors such as sampling bias, question wording, and survey methodology can also impact the accuracy of the results.
